reviewText:
This game is about clicking on badguys to deal damage and then moving onto the next stage to do the same thing.
You may read that, look at the name of the game and immediately assume its an idle clicker game where you can progress while AFK. It isn't, oddly enough and that makes it difficult to talk about in a meaningful way.

Clicker games are very niche, they appeal to the part of your brain that loves to feel like you outsmarted someone or something and we all have fun finding the most optimum route or making the maximum clicks per second bot. ECJ comes so very close to that but it has 2 fatal flaws that prevent it being a true clicker experience.

First of all, you can't idle. You can in the literal sense but not the figurative sense because when you finish a wave, you can never automatically go on to the next wave, ever. So you need to constantly loot a treasure chest and then go back to the world map and then move on or re-do the same map, every time.

Secondly you can only have 1 pet and DPS scales at +1 per level so Lv10 DPS = 10 DPS which is so small its useless and the grind to make it useful is so high that you really need not bother. Click damage all the way for this one.

I don't think ECJ is bad but who do i recommend it too? If you like idle clicker games then maybe you will get something out of it? If you like regular video games or RPGs then why not play something better like just about any actual RPG?

Also features microtransactions because of course it does but everything you can buy, you can get for free. Yes even those 'exclusive monsters' that cost diamonds, you can obtain for free. Get a pokeball item and use it on any monster in the game to obtain them. May sound a bit borken until you realize you can only have 1 pet and you are stuck with it till it dies, at which point you can revive it for the small fee of real life cash. Not sure why you'd want too really, they don't offer all that much except 0 or 1 or 2 pockets for items and insultingly small DPS.

I don't hate this game but its kind of a shallow experience, kind of disappointing really given all its negative reviews.

reviewText:
Epic Clicker Journey game is a brand new type of clicker.
It combines clicker and adventure in one game. Most of people thinks of it as an idle clicker - that's why it misses potential for them, but the point is that this clicker has kinda plot as well. There are limited locations on this map (20) and 3 levels of difficulty. I guess it allows this clicker to be expanded easily in the future (I' m really wainting for it!). For me it's refreshing that this clicker has an end which can be developed later, for example as new maps and locations - not just repeating the same locations and creatures/minions/whatelse endlessly.
I like to play RPG games so the feature of getting loot, EXP, and having HP is really cool! I love this idea! But I think loot can be further developed, because it's really missleading right now. It lack some kind of tooltip or other in-game explanation what it actually does.
In this game a very important thing is strategy. It's not a clicker where u click and kill mindlessly. You have to think! Am I strong enough to kill this minion? No? I have to run! Or else I will lose my loot! RPG players will like it (well, I liked that).
Overall, this game has a great potential to be brand new clicker. It has lots of new features which other clickers don't provide. I just hope it will be further developed, map will be expanded, and more epic loot will be added :D

There is nothing of value to see here.  If you REALLY have an itch for a F2P clicker game, there exists better ones on Steam.

reviewText:
**QUICK THOUGHTS**

While I've already clocked in over 13 hours at the time of jotting down these thoughts, I can't say they have all been that pleasurable. When I started out I enjoyed the clicker game change of pace this title presented, offering up levels strewn about on a map with various enemies you need to defeat before you can advance. Multiplayer levels offer keys which are needed to advance further until the map is complete. Repeat two more times. However, by the time I got half way through the map the first time, it started to lose its lustre.

A lot of the images look crudely hand drawn, which, again, is a nice change of pace from the norm of stock images or cutesy foes you click on. However, most are just satirical pop culture creations like the xenomorph from Alien being drawn like a cat with a collar, sexy mermaid, Freddy Kreuger, Twilight characters... the list goes on. The levels are somewhat animated at times as well, though for the most part just background things moving about left and right.

You collect coins to raise your attack, health and how much damage you can block, as well as level up to increase your base stats of DMG, DPS, DEF, and LUCK. There's a lot of grinding involved and I often find myself leaving the game running in the background with the DPS and my fellow" (which you can buy in the store for additional damage and level up later) attack automatically. There's also random items you get from the chests at the end of each battle you can sell off or equip that confused me a bit at first until the developer put up a guide as to what many of them do (thank you for that by the way).

While I found much of this noble at the beginning

Spoiler Alert: You can literally hack all your stats (Money, Diamonds, Skillpoints, Stats, Fellow DPS, Health, etc.) with plain old cheat engine. It's literally as easy as, find the value, change it, done.  I mean... c'mon now... If that alone doesn't speak for the quality of this game, well then I dunno what else to tell 'ya.

For those who maybe want a little more of a genuine review:

Pros:
- Interesting concept for a clicker game
- Good effort to try and redefine the clicker genre
- Mildly satisfying player progression (In terms of leveling & Equipment)
- Free to play

Cons:
- Microtransactions
- Levels feel too samey
- Dreadful game progression (As in you'll breeze through the first 3 levels, and then you have to grind just to beat the 4th, and so on)
- Laughably easy to cheat
- Clearly built to encourage microtransactions
- Regenning health between levels is painfully slow.
- #NoMoreHashTags #GivemeActualInformationOnTheseItems
- Incredibly shallow click-speed cap. As in, I average 13 CPS without an auto-clicker, and the cap is like 4 CPS before the game stops registering clicks.
- Subjectively poor/mediocre art/effects quality


The bottom line is, this game was good in theory, but lacked execution. Ultimately it's painfully clear that this is a low-budget, low-quality game designed ideally for the sake of conning unassuming individuals out of their money, at least as far as I can tell.

Epic Clicker Journey:

Positive points:
-Clicking actually does things. Damage FTW
- Cutesie monsters, my little pony in bondage, that sorta thing, really weirdball
- Decent progression, generally, you're not stuck for too long on any spot

- Nothing aside from more item slots needs real money (and you don't need those really)
- it's free
- You can click the title screen, instead of clicking continue, and the epic and journey will fall off

Cons
- No idling possible
- The second offhand item of another weapon seems to be useless
- stats aren't explained
- little to no story
- confusing
- ending? no story, so no ending :S

End judgement: It's a nice free game, where at the end, you still have energy/time/desire to get the last boss to not do any damage to you ever again. The lack of story is a little bit offputting, but eventually, this time of mine, probably a bit slow (take off an hour or so if you're great!) is what it takes to finish.

The tactic to beat this game seems simple enough, just upgrade your armor, until they can't hurt you anymore...
